thread.title: Timofey Mozgov frustrated with repaired knee: 'It's still bothering me'
thread.title_full: Timofey Mozgov frustrated with repaired knee: 'It's still bothering me' | cleveland.com

author: Chris Haynes, Northeast Ohio Media Group
title: Timofey Mozgov frustrated with repaired knee: 'It's still bothering me'
text:
INDEPENDENCE, Ohio â€“ Cleveland Cavaliers center Timofey Mozgov was visibly frustrated towards the end of practice on Wednesday.
At the completion of a rigorous workout, Mozgov, who is recovering from having his right knee scoped over the summer, explained the source of that frustration.
"My knee is not -- I wish it could be like it's not bothering me, but it is what it is," Mozgov said. "It's bothering me, but we're still working on it. Not before the first game, but in the close future, we will be good. I hope so."
For about 45 minutes, assistant coaches Tyronn Lue and Larry Drew along with assistant player development coach Vitaly Potapenko worked with Mozgov on his post moves. They stressed the need to back his defender down for closer field goal opportunities and urged him not to settle for long hooks outside of the paint. The staff put him through a great deal of repetitions, then instruction, followed by more reps.
At one point, a discouraged-looking Mozgov pointed to his knee as to why he couldn't move like he wanted. Yet still, he continued on.
The organization has been cautious with his workload.
Of the three back-to-back sets Cleveland had on its schedule during the preseason, Mozgov only participated in the final pair. He wanted to see how his knee would feel after a back-to-back before the regular season tipped off on Oct. 27 against the Chicago Bulls.
"I'm happy with how my body responded to back-to-back, but I'm still not happy where my body is at right now," he said. "[I'm not happy] by the shape, by my knee, whatever."
It's clearly an annoying situation. When he was first asked about the knee, he responded: "You asked me again, so you want the same answer?"
Head coach David Blatt was under the weather and did not speak to media. So how he plans to utilize Varejao in practices before the season remains unknown.
Considering Mozgov made it through the exhibition season averaging 24.8 minutes over five games, he appears to be headed on the right track. But it appears there's going to be more pain and frustration before a full bill of health follows.
"I think it's not really bad," he said.
